citeinfo.title: Environmental Studies of Macrozoobenthos, Aquatic Macrophytes, and Juvenile Fishes in the St. Clair-Detroit River System, 1983-1984: Hoopnet Sampling Record for Fish

descript.abstract: This hoopnet sampling record for fish data set was collected for use in the administrative report entitled "Environmental Studies of Macrozoobenthos, Aquatic Macrophytes, and Juvenile Fishes in the St. Clair-Detroit River System, 1983-1984". It is a portion of the data collected for this administrative report, which provided information needed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers for preparation of a Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement addressing the winter operation of the lock facilities at Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan, and the subsequent extension of the navigation season in the St. Clair-Detroit River system (SCDRS) to January-February. The following is excerpted from the original report's abstract: We describe the distribution and abundance of macrozoobenthos, aquatic macrophytes and juvenile fishes during the 1983 and 1984 open water season, and attempt to predict or evaluate the potential environmental impact of an extended navigation season on the biota of SCDRS. Fauna and flora were diverse and abundant; we identified more than 300 taxa of macrozoobenthos, 30 taxa of submergent and emergent macrophytes, and 36 species of fish. The diversity and abundance of macrozoobenthos were generally highest in the St. Clair River. Abundance and diversity of submersed macrophytes were similar in the two rivers, but Chara dominated in the St. Clair River and Vallisneria americana in the Detroit River. We collected more total fish in the Detroit River but more species in the St. Clair River. Yellow perch and rock bass dominated most catches in both rivers. An ice jam in the St. Clair River in spring 1984 appeared to affect two of the three groups studied--macroinvertebrates and submersed macrophytes. Of the 24 abundant taxa of macroinvertebrates, 9 were seemingly less abundant in spring in 1984 than in 1983 in the St. Clair River; however the densities of 6 of these taxa had recovered by fall 1984 to levels equal to or exceeding those in fall 1983 and the other 3 were within 30% of those in 1983. Cover of the bottom with submersed macrophytes was somewhat reduced in spring of 1984--particularly in the St. Clair River--but recovered to 1983 levels by fall 1984. Plant biomass levels varied between years and locations; no consistent differences could be attributed to the ice jam. Catches of fish were lower in 1984 than in 1983 but differences between locations and months were inconsistent. Observed differences in the plant community could be attributed to reduced temperatures, and ice-scour may have reduced the density of several taxa of macrozoobenthos. Evaluation of the potential environmental impacts of an extended navigation season on the biota of SCDRS was not attempted.
descript.purpose: These data describe the distribution and abundance of fish, and attempt to predict or evaluate the potential environmental impact of an extended navigation season on the biota of SCDR. These data were collected for a USACOE Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement addressing the winter operation of the lock facilities at Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan, and the subsequent extension of the navigation season in the St. Clair-Detroit River system (SCDRS) to January-February.
descript.supplinf: This hoopnet sampling record for fish data set was created for the use in the titled report to administration. It contains sample location, environmental conditions, species, life stage, length, weight, and catch numbers. Fish were sampled with hoop nets in the St. Clair River at Stag, Fawn, and Russell islands, and in the Detroit River at Belle Isle, Point Hennepin, and Stony Island (Fig. 4) during late May, late June, late July-early August, early September, and early October in 1983 and 1984. The nets were 2.5 feet in diameter and 10 feet long, and constructed of 1-inch (stretched measure) nylon mesh. Each net was fitted with wings about 6 feet long and 3 feet high, constructed of 2-inch mesh nylon. Nets were set in the gridded area used for macrophyte sampling, in water 3-6 ft deep, for 24 hours; the net mouth faced downstream. At each location, two nets were set in submersed aquatic vegetation and two others in nearby non-vegetated areas. Fish caught in each set were sorted to species, weighed to the nearest gram, measured (total length to the nearest millimeter), and released. Age was determined by consulting age-at-length records for fishes of Ohio, including western Lake Erie (Trautman 1981). More detailed methodology available in report, which also includes the following related appendices: Q: Catch Data for Hoop Nets, R: ANOVA Tables for Fish, S: Physical Data for Hoop Net Sites.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: This data was collected for reporting to the Department of the Army, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Detroit-District, Detroit, Michigan 48231. The scientific review process for this report may differ from other publication types. Users are advised to read the data set's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

procstep.procdesc: Development of the data set by the agency / individuals identified in the 'Originator' element in the Identification Info section of the record.

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

attr.attrdef: File names of original electronic data sources

attrdomv.udom: 3-digit number representing the form used to collect original data in the field

attr.attrdef: Lake or river where sample was taken
Corresponds to island location where sample taken

attrdomv.udom: Single digit corresponds to island in river where sample taken: Stag, Fawn, Russell, Belle, Hennepin, Stony

attr.attrdef: Station number; the depth/part of the river where sample was collected

attrdomv.udom: Single digit values 1-4 corresponding to part of river where sample collected

attr.attrdef: Numeric code used for organism species identification. Fish species names originate from the American Fisheries Society.

Life stage of fish species caught for each sample. [Note from Appendix Q of report: by convention, fish are assumed to pass into the next year of life on January 1. All ages were drived from lengths, as reported by Trautman (1981).]

edom.edomvd: fish in the first year of life (young-of-the-year)
fish in the second year of life (yearlings)
fish in the second or later year of life
fish in the third or later year of life

attr.attrdef: Number of fish caught for each species and life stage per sample
Range of fish length in millimeters (mm)

attrdomv.udom: Contains 2 numbers, each 2-3 digits, representing a length range; not separated by hyphen. Need to check against report data tables to confirm values.

attr.attrdef: Total weight of fish for species and life stage grouping collected in sample
Card number used to collect data

attrdomv.udom: All values are '2' for this table/dataset
